questions.text: A female patient presents with swollen Bartholin glands. Discharging pus showed Gram-negative intracellular diplococci. Which is the organism?(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a Gram-negative diplococcus that is often found intracellularly within neutrophils. It is a common cause of sexually transmitted infections, including infections of the Bartholin glands. The typical presentation includes swelling and pus discharge, which is consistent with the given clinical scenario.

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is characterized by its kidney or bean shape and lack of a capsule, unlike Neisseria meningitidis, which is capsulated. It is known for causing sexually transmitted infections, including those affecting the genital tract, such as Bartholin gland abscesses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Although Chlamydia can cause genital infections, it is not a Gram-negative diplococcus. Instead, it is an obligate intracellular bacterium with a unique developmental cycle.

 

Option C. Chancroid: Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, chancroid is a Gram-negative bacillus and not a diplococcus.

 

Option D. Syphilis: Caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete, which is not a Gram-negative diplococcus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a Gram-negative intracellular diplococcus, is the causative agent of gonorrhea and can infect the Bartholin glands, leading to swelling and pus discharge.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of Mollicutes? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureaplasma urealyticum

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall.

 

They vary in form, although most have sterols that make the cell membrane somewhat more rigid.

 

Many are able to move about through gliding, but members of the genus Spiroplasma are helical and move by twisting.

 

The best-known genus in the Mollicutes is Mycoplasma. Colonies show the typical “fried-egg” appearance.

 

Mollicutes are parasites of various animals and plants, living on or in the host’s cells. Many cause diseases in humans, attaching to cells in the respiratory or urogenital tracts, particularly species of Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma. Phytoplasma and Spiroplasma are plant pathogens associated with insect vectors.

 

Ureaplasma urealyticum has the ability to hydrolyse urea. It causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Orientia tsutsugamushi: This bacterium belongs to the family Rickettsiaceae and is the causative agent of scrub typhus, which is transmitted by mites.

 

Option C. Chlamydophila pneumonia: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydophila, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes respiratory infections.

 

Option D. Chlamydia trachomatis: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydia, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes various infections, including trachoma and sexually transmitted infections.

 

Educational Objective

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall. The most well-known genera in this class are Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma, with Ureaplasma urealyticum being a notable example that causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

questions.text: Farmer with traumatic ulcer in eye and septate hyphae seen. Causative organism is ? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspergillus

 

Explanation:

 

Farmers often suffer from injuries involving organic matter. The presence of a traumatic ulcer in the eye coupled with the identification of septate hyphae points toward a fungal infection.

 

Between Mucor and Aspergillus, the distinguishing factor is the type of hyphae. Aspergillus forms septate hyphae, meaning the hyphae have regular, cross-wall divisions. In contrast, Mucor forms aseptate (or coenocytic) hyphae, which lack these septa.

 

 

Characteristic of Hyphae -

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor: Although Mucor is a fungus that can cause infections, it forms aseptate hyphae. This characteristic helps differentiate it from Aspergillus in cases of fungal eye infections.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pyogenes: This bacterium can cause various infections, including those in the eye, but it does not form hyphae. Thus, it cannot be the causative organism in this scenario.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas: This is another bacterium that can cause eye infections, particularly in the context of contact lens wearers, but like Streptococcus pyogenes, it does not form hyphae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of septate hyphae in an eye infection suggests Aspergillus as the causative organism.

questions.text: A child presented with intense perianal itching. Mother complains of seeing thread like worms in the perianal area. Scotch tape method was used to collect sample and showed these eggs in stool. Identify the organism? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enterobius vermicularis

 

Enterobius vermicularis, commonly known as pinworm, threadworm, or seatworm, is the causative agent of enterobiasis. The characteristic presentation includes intense perianal itching, especially at night when the gravid female worms migrate to the perianal area to deposit eggs. The eggs are planoconvex (D-shaped or flattened on one side and convex on the other), colorless, non-bile stained, and float in saturated salt solution. 

 

The Scotch tape method (also called cellophane tape test) is the diagnostic test of choice, where transparent adhesive tape is pressed against the perianal skin in the morning before bathing to collect eggs for microscopic examination. The adult worms are small, white, and thread-like, resembling short pieces of thread, which explains why the mother could see them.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascaris lumbricoides: Causes ascariasis with eggs that are bile-stained, round, and have a mammillated outer coat. Does not cause perianal itching, and diagnosis is made by finding eggs in stool examination, not by Scotch tape method.

 

Option C. Hymenolepis nana: The dwarf tapeworm produces eggs that are non-bile stained and float in salt solution but are round with polar filaments and an inner membrane containing hexacanth embryo. Does not cause the characteristic perianal itching.

 

Option D. Hookworm: Includes Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus. Their eggs are oval, non-bile stained but don't cause perianal itching. Infection occurs through skin penetration by filariform larvae, not by ingestion of eggs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterobius vermicularis causes intense perianal itching with thread-like worms visible to naked eye, diagnosed by Scotch tape method showing characteristic D-shaped (planoconvex) eggs.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

 

History of fever with liver and kidney involvement should arouse suspicion for leptospirosis (Weil's disease).

 

A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

 

Serotype-specific tests:

 

  • Microscopic agglutination test
  • Macroscopic agglutination test

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Widal test: Incorrect, the Widal test is used to diagnose typhoid fever, which involves testing for antibodies against Salmonella typhi antigens but does not present with the same symptom profile as described.

 

Option C. Weil Felix reaction: Incorrect, this test is historically used for diagnosing rickettsial infections, which are caused by different organisms and have different clinical features.

 

Option D. Paul Bunnell test (monospot test): Incorrect, this test is used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, characterized by symptoms like fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes but not typically associated with icterus or hematuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 The Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is crucial for diagnosing leptospirosis in patients presenting with symptoms like fever, jaundice, red eyes, and hematuria, as it accurately detects the presence of antibodies against Leptospira, confirming the infection.

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aedes aegypti

 

Zika virus may be transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

 

The symptoms of Zika virus disease include fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, or headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days.

 

Zika virus infection during pregnancy may cause lead to microcephaly or congenital Zika syndrome.

 

The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Culex: This genus of mosquitoes is not a known vector for Zika virus but is commonly associated with the transmission of the West Nile virus.

 

Option C. Anopheles: Known primarily for transmitting malaria, not Zika virus.

 

Option D. Phlebotomus papatasii: These are sandflies and known vectors for the virus causing leishmaniasis, not Zika.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are the primary vectors for the transmission of Zika virus. Effective prevention and control measures involve protecting against mosquito bites through the use of insect repellents, bed nets, and eliminating standing water where mosquitoes breed. Awareness of the risks associated with Zika, particularly for pregnant women, is crucial for preventing infection and its severe consequences.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by the vector shown below? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orientia

 

Explanation:

 

Orientia, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is transmitted by chigger mites, not by the tick shown in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Babesia: Transmitted by ticks

 

Option C. Ehrlichia: Also transmitted by ticks

 

Option D. Crimean congo hemorrhagic fever : Also transmitted by ticks

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi, responsible for scrub typhus, is not transmitted by ticks but by chigger mites, distinguishing it from other tick-borne infections like Babesia and Ehrlichia.

questions.text: Which virus can be identified by a PCR method and is endemic to India? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) West Nile Virus

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can cause neurological disease and death in people. WNV is commonly found in Africa, Europe, the Middle East, North America and West Asia. In Mumbai in the year 1952, the antibodies against WNV were first detected in humans. Since then, the virus activity has been reported in southern, central, and western India. WNV is maintained in nature in a cycle involving transmission between birds and mosquitoes. Humans, horses and other mammals can be infected.

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) is a member of the flavivirus genus and belongs to the Japanese encephalitis antigenic complex of the family Flaviviridae.

 

West Nile virus can be diagnosed by a number of different tests:

 

  • IgG antibody sero-conversion (or significant increase in antibody titers) in two serial specimen collected at a one week interval by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • IgM antibody capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • neutralisation assays;
  • viral detection by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay, and
  • virus isolation by cell culture.

 

IgM can be detected in nearly all cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and serum specimens received from WNV infected patients at the time of their clinical presentation. Serum IgM antibody may persist for more than a year.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: Hendra virus is endemic to Australia

 

Option C: Ebola virus is endemic to Africa.

 

Option D: Yellow fever endemic to South and Central America, and certain parts of Africa.

 

Educational Objective

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can be identified by PCR and is endemic to India, with significant historical and ongoing presence, making it a critical pathogen for regional public health monitoring and response.

questions.text: Which of the following causes aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parvovirus

 

ParvoVirus-B19 infects erythroid progenitor cells and inhibits erythropoiesis, leading to acute erythroblastopenia and reticulocytopenia. The bone marrow in patients with transient aplastic crisis is characterized by an absence of maturing erythroid precursors and presence of giant pro-normoblasts. Although giant pro-normoblasts are suggestive of parvovirus B19 infection, they are not diagnostic of the disease. Aplastic crisis in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis is because of pancytopenia accompanied with a marked decrease in reticulocytes. Bone marrow aspiration may not be routinely required when viral infection-induced aplastic crisis is highly suspected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Poxvirus: Poxviruses are not associated with causing aplastic crisis.

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr virus: While Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) can cause hematologic abnormalities, it is not typically associated with causing aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option C. Adenovirus: Adenovirus infections are common but are not known to cause aplastic crisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 is the causative agent for aplastic crisis in patients with hereditary spherocytosis. It infects erythroid progenitor cells, inhibiting erythropoiesis and leading to a significant decrease in reticulocytes, causing acute erythroblastopenia.

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the image below? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HIV

 

The image shows an HIV virus.

 

  • It is an enveloped virus with positive-sense single-stranded RNA as its genetic material.
  • HIV primarily infects CD4+ T cells and macrophages.
  • Laboratory diagnosis of HIV infection involves screening tests (EIA/CLIA) and confirmatory tests (Western blot/immunofluorescence assays).
  • Antiretroviral therapy (ART) aims to suppress viral replication, reduce viral load, preserve immune function, and improve quality of life.
  • Prevention strategies include safe sex practices, sterile needle use, HIV testing and counselling, and pre-exposure prophylaxis for high-risk individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): A member of the herpesvirus family associated with infectious mononucleosis and certain cancers. Structure is shown below.

 

 

 

Option C. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Another herpesvirus, known for causing infections in immunocompromised individuals, particularly different in structure.

 

 

Option D. Coronavirus: Known for its crown-like appearance under electron microscopy and causes respiratory illnesses like COVID-19.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

HIV is an enveloped virus with positive-sense single-stranded RNA, known for targeting CD4+ T cells and macrophages, and is identified by the presence of gp120 and gp41 glycoproteins on its surface.

choices.text: Real-time PCR to detect viral mRNA
Rapid antigen test to detect spike proteins

questions.text: SARS-Cov-2 can be detected by all except? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Southern blotting

 

Southern Blotting: This technique is used for the detection of specific DNA sequences in DNA samples. This is not applicable for detecting SARS-CoV-2 because the virus is RNA-based and there is not enough DNA in the collected samples to obtain a pattern on gel electrophoresis. RNA viruses require different techniques such as RT-PCR for detection.

 

Other Options

 

Tests for SARS CoV2

 

  • Real-time PCR (RT-PCR):

  • Method: This technique is used to detect the presence of viral RNA. Nasopharyngeal swabs are typically used as the sample source.

  • Explanation: It is the most sensitive and specific test available for SARS-CoV-2 detection.

  • Rapid Antigen Test:

  • Method: This test detects specific proteins, such as the spike protein, from the virus present in nasopharyngeal secretions.

  • Explanation: It provides quicker results compared to PCR but is generally less sensitive.

  • ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay):

  • Method: This technique detects antibodies against spike proteins or the spike proteins themselves.

  • Explanation: It is used for both diagnostic and serological purposes.

 

Educational Objective

 

Southern blotting is not a suitable method for detecting SARS-CoV-2 as it is designed to detect DNA, while SARS-CoV-2 is an RNA virus and requires RNA-specific detection techniques.

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines could have prevented it? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 17D

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of yellow fever and the use of 17D vaccine could have prevented this.

 

17D vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine administered through the subcutaneous route. It is contraindicated in infants less than 9 months of age, in pregnancy, and in individuals with egg allergy.

 

Yellow fever is caused by flavivirus and is endemic to certain parts of Africa and America. It occurs in two patterns: the urban cycle and the sylvatic cycle. Aedes aegypti is the vector in the urban cycle, while Aedes africanus is responsible for transmission in the sylvatic cycle.

 

Patients present with acute onset fever, headache, and vomiting. Jaundice and hemorrhagic manifestations can also be present. Ultimately, hepatic or renal failure can result in death.

 

Torres bodies are intranuclear eosinophilic inclusion bodies in hepatocytes. These are rarely seen in yellow fever. To prevent the establishment of the disease in India, strict vaccination and quarantine protocols for travelers from endemic areas are enforced.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: Nakayama vaccine is used for immunization against Japanese encephalitis. Culex tritaeniorhynchus is the principal vector. There is a sudden onset of fever and vomiting, which later progresses to encephalitis. In India, it was first reported in Vellore and continues to be active in the country.

 

Option C. Weigl's vaccine is the earliest used vaccine against epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The main foci of the disease are Europe, Africa, South America, and Asia. Kashmir is the endemic spot in India. Pediculus humans corporis (human body louse) is the vector. Symptoms include fever and chills. A characteristic rash on the trunk and limbs, sparing the face, palms, and soles, may also be seen.

 

Option D. Jeryl-Lynn strain of the mumps virus is used against the disease as a live-attenuated vaccine. It is contraindicated in pregnancy and individuals allergic to eggs. Mumps present as parotid swelling associated with fever and tenderness.

 

Educational Objective

 

The 17D vaccine could have prevented the yellow fever that led to the photographer's severe symptoms and death. This highlights the importance of appropriate vaccination before traveling to areas where yellow fever is endemic.

questions.text: A patient presented with a prolonged fever of unknown origin (PUO), raising suspicion of brucellosis. To confirm the diagnosis, various dilutions of the patient's serum sample are prepared for a standard agglutination test. The outcome is as follows: No agglutination is observed at serum dilutions of 1:20 and 1:40, while positive agglutination occurs at dilutions of 1:80 and 1:160. What factor is accountable for the lack of agglutination in the initial two dilutions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibody excess

 

  • Marrack proposed the lattice hypothesis → Multivalent antigens combine with Bivalent antibodies
  • Lattice is formed only when antigen and antibodies are in proportion.
  • If antigen or antibodies ,any of them is in excess - there is no lattice formation
  • The absence of a positive test result in the initial two tubes can be attributed to the prozone phenomenon.
  • In this scenario, there is an excess of antibodies in comparison to antigens, which results in a lack of robust or noticeable precipitation.

 

Zone phenomenon:

 

  1. Prozone = Ab excess = Absent
  2. Zone of equivalence = Proper proportion = Peak
  3. Post zone = Ag excess = Absent

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Incorrect antigen: If the antigen were incorrect, there would be no agglutination at any dilution.

 

Option B. Incorrect antibody: If the antibody were incorrect, there would be no agglutination at any dilution.

 

Option D. Antigen excess: Antigen excess would cause a postzone phenomenon, not observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prozone phenomenon, where antibody excess prevents agglutination, can account for the lack of agglutination in low dilution samples.

questions.text: A patient addressing from Delhi presents with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm3, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm3, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dengue

 

The patient with given symptoms and lab results, points out to diagnosis of dengue fever.

 

Dengue, aka Break Bone Fever

 

 

Shown below is an image of the rash in dengue:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria patients presents with clinical features like periodic bouts of fever with chills and rigors, followed by anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.

 

Option C. Scrub typhus patients typically presents with a characteristic eschar, which is a punched-out ulcer covered with a blackened scab at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. Here’s an image of the eschar.

 

 

Option D. Typhoid (enteric) fever presents with fever, abdominal pain, headache, chills, myalgia, malaise, diarrhea, sweating, nausea, and vomiting. Rose spots are classical, pink macules on the abdomen and the chest. Hepatosplenomegaly and relative bradycardia might be seen. The WBC count vary from normal to low.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of fever, arthralgia, petechial rash, and significant thrombocytopenia in a patient from an area where dengue is endemic should prompt immediate consideration of dengue fever, with prompt initiation of supportive care and monitoring for potential complications such as DHF or DSS.

questions.text: The culture from a pustular lesion showed hemolytic gram-positive cocci. A provisional diagnosis of Group A streptococcal pyoderma can be made by: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Bacitracin sensitivity

 

Explanation:

 

Bacitracin sensitivity testing is the most appropriate method for the provisional diagnosis of Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) from pustular lesions. Group A streptococci characteristically show susceptibility to bacitracin, which serves as a key diagnostic feature in the laboratory. This susceptibility helps differentiate S. pyogenes from other beta-hemolytic streptococci. The test is performed by placing a bacitracin disk on a culture plate and observing for a zone of inhibition around the disk, which indicates susceptibility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase positivity - This is incorrect because streptococci, including Group A Streptococcus, are catalase negative. The catalase test helps differentiate staphylococci (catalase positive) from streptococci (catalase negative). Finding catalase positivity would actually point away from streptococcal infection and toward staphylococcal infection.

 

Option B. Optochin sensitivity - This is incorrect because optochin sensitivity is specifically used for identifying Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococci), not Group A streptococci. S. pneumoniae is highly sensitive to optochin, while other streptococci including Group A are typically resistant.

 

Option C. Bile solubility - This is incorrect because the bile solubility test is used primarily for identifying Streptococcus pneumoniae. Pneumococci are soluble in bile whereas other streptococci, including Group A Streptococcus, are not bile soluble. This test would not help confirm a Group A streptococcal infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacitracin sensitivity testing is the key diagnostic test for the provisional identification of Group A Streptococcus from clinical specimens, with sensitivity to bacitracin being a distinctive characteristic that helps differentiate it from other beta-hemolytic streptococci.

questions.text: A militant presents with rashes all over his body sparing the palms and soles. On examination, he was febrile and lice were noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rickettsia prowazekii

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic or louse-borne typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.

 

Pediculus corporis (human body louse) is the vector for the parasite, although the head louse may also transmit the disease. After the incubation period of 5 - 15 days, the disease typically starts with fever and chills. By around 4 - 5th day of fever, a characteristic rash appears, which starts on the trunk and spreads over the limbs but spares the face, palms, and soles.

 

The infection can be transmitted by

 

  • Contaminated louse feces rubbed through abrasions caused by scratching
  • Inhalation of aerosols of dried louse feces or directly through the conjunctiva

 

The disease is often severe with the fever lasting for over 2 weeks and is more fatal in patients older than 40 years of age.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia typhi causes murine (flea-borne) or endemic typhus. Rats are the reservoirs of infection and the parasite is transmitted by Xenopsylla cheopis (flea). The infection is transmitted when the flea feces is rubbed into the bite wound. The clinical features are similar to that of epidemic typhus but are milder and rarely fatal.

 

Patients can present with fever, headache, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C. Rickettsia akari causes rickettsial pox, which is a mild disease resembling varicella. The disease is transmitted by mites and the patients may present with fever, headache, and a vesicular rash.

 

Option D. Rickettsia conorii causes the Mediterranean spotted fever. The parasite is transmitted by ticks and the patients present with fever, headache, rash, and eschar (tache noire).

 

Educational Objective

 

Rickettsia prowazekii, transmitted by body lice, causes epidemic typhus, which is characterized by a rash that begins on the trunk and spreads to the extremities while sparing the face, palms, and soles. Awareness of this disease's clinical features and transmission methods is essential for preventing outbreaks in high-risk environments.

questions.text: A HIV patient is presenting with cough without sputum, on examination his CD4 counts were <100 and chest x ray shown bilateral infiltration of lung, on further proceeding Bronchoalveolar lavage is done and the organisms were positive for acid fast staining, what is the organism responsible for his condition? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium avium complex

 

Based on the clinical presentation, CD4 count, radiographic findings, and positive acid-fast staining in the bronchoalveolar lavage, the most likely organism responsible for the patient's condition is Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC), which is a group of bacteria that can cause lung infections in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV/AIDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumocystis jirovecii is a fungus that commonly causes pneumonia in people with weakened immune systems, including those with HIV/AIDS. However, the cough in this case is without sputum, which is not typical of Pneumocystis pneumonia. Although PCP is common in patients with CD4 counts <100 cells/µL, it does not stain positive for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus is a fungus that can cause a severe lung infection and meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not stain positive for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that can cause lung infections in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not typically present with a positive acid-fast stain and is not commonly associated with lung infiltrates seen on chest X-rays in patients with advanced HIV/AIDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HIV patients with CD4 counts <100 cells/µL presenting with a cough without sputum, bilateral lung infiltrates on chest x-ray, and positive acid-fast staining, Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is the most likely causative organism.

questions.text: Which of the following is Burkholderia cepacia resistant to? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cefotetan

 

Burkholderia cepacia complex is known for its intrinsic resistance to various antimicrobial agents, including cefotetan.

 

B. Cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to:

 

  • Aminoglycosides
  • Polymixin
  • First and second-generation cephalosporins
  • Carboxypenicillins

 

B. Cepacia can cause severe necrotizing pneumonia in patients with chronic granulomatous disease. It can lead to fatal septicemia in patients with cystic fibrosis.

 

Antimicrobial agents that are effective against B. cepacia complex include:

 

  • Meropenem
  • Ceftazidime
  • Piperacillin
  • Temocillin
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ceftazidime: Incorrect because ceftazidime is actually among the antimicrobials that are effective against B. cepacia complex, suggesting it can bypass the bacterium’s resistance mechanisms.

 

Option B. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole: Incorrect, as this combination is also effective against B. cepacia, demonstrating its capability to treat infections caused by this pathogen.

 

Option C. Temocillin: Incorrect, as temocillin is listed as effective against B. cepacia complex, indicating its efficacy in combating this resistant bacterium.

 

Educational Objective

 

Burkholderia cepacia exhibits resistance to several antibiotic classes, including second-generation cephalosporins like cefotetan.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the OPD with painful genital ulcers. Which of the following can cause a painful ulcer on the glans penis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chancroid

 

Painful genital ulcer is caused by Chancroid.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: The primary lesion of syphilis, known as a chancre, is typically painless. It is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum and usually presents as a firm, round, and painless ulcer.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis infection can cause genital ulcers but these are generally painless and associated with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). Chlamydia can cause urethritis, cervicitis, and other non-ulcerative conditions but is not typically associated with painful genital ulcers.

 

Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV): LGV is a chronic infection of the lymphatic system caused by certain serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis. The primary lesion is usually a painless genital ulcer or papule, which may go unnoticed by the patient.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions
It is not a sexually transmitted infection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

 

Trichomonas vaginalis has a jerky or twitching type of motility on the wet saline mount.

 

Lab Diagnosis for Trichomonas:

 

  1. Direct Microscopy: Wet (saline) mount of fresh samples jerky motile trophozoites and pus cells. Cystic stage not seen.
  2. Culture: Gold standard method for diagnosis.
  3. Serology: Antigen Detection in Vaginal Secretion:
    • More sensitive than microscopy
    • Indicates recent infection
    • ELISA uses monoclonal antibodies.
    • Antibody Detection by ELISA - whole cell antigen preparation
  4. Molecular Methods: Highly sensitive targeting T. vaginalis specific genes - beta-tubulin gene.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It cannot be cultured: Incorrect, as Trichomonas vaginalis can indeed be cultured and this is considered the gold standard for its diagnosis.

 

Option C. Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions: Incorrect, Trichomonas vaginalis does not produce cysts; it exists only in trophozoite form.

 

Option D. It is not a sexually transmitted infection: Incorrect, as it is a well-known sexually transmitted infection.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Heat till it become red hot

questions.text: Inoculation loops are commonly sterilized by which method? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Heat till it becomes red hot

 

Inoculation loops are typically made of nichrome wire with a circular structure at one end and a wooden handle. The most appropriate method for sterilizing these loops is heating them until they become red hot, which is a type of physical heat method. This method ensures complete sterilization of the metal portion of the loop that comes in contact with microorganisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoclaving:

 

  • Incorrect because autoclaving is not suitable for inoculation loops as it would be impractical and unnecessary
  • Autoclaving is primarily used for bulk sterilization of media, equipment, and materials at 121°C for 15 minutes at 15 PSI

 

Option B. Microwave:

 

  • Incorrect because microwave sterilization is not appropriate for metal objects like inoculation loops
  • Microwaves can cause arcing with metal objects and potentially damage the equipment

 

Option C. Passing over flame 3 times:

 

  • Incorrect because this method is specifically used for degreasing glass slides
  • This technique would not provide sufficient heat to ensure complete sterilization of the inoculation loop

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Inoculation loops must be sterilized by heating till red hot to ensure complete elimination of microorganisms, as this is the most effective and practical physical heat method for these instruments.

choices.text: Albendazole is the drug of choice
Majority of infections are asymptomatic in humans
Infection is acquired by ingestion of aquatic plants

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the given image is correct? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Majority of infections are asymptomatic in humans

 

The given image shows hymenolepis nana egg. Egg is spherical or ovoid and has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar. Filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

Hymenolepis nana is the smallest and the most common tapeworm found in the human intestine.

 

Hymenolepiasis occurs more commonly in children. There are usually no symptoms but in heavy infections, there is nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea and irritability. Sometimes pruritus may occur due to an allergic response.

 

Praziquantel (single dose of 25 mg/kg) is the drug of choice, since it acts both against the adult worms and the cysticercoids in the intestinal villi. Nitazoxanide 500 mg BD for 3 days may be used as alternative.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Albendazole is the drug of choice: This is incorrect. The drug of choice for Hymenolepis nana is praziquantel (a single dose of 25 mg/kg) because it acts against both adult worms and the cysticercoids in the intestinal villi. Nitazoxanide (500 mg BD for 3 days) may be used as an alternative.

 

Option C. Infection is acquired by ingestion of aquatic plants: This is incorrect. The infection with Hymenolepis nana is not acquired through aquatic plants. Infections are usually acquired by ingestion of contaminated food or water or by autoinfection.

 

Option D. Non-segmented leaf-like parasite: This is incorrect. Hymenolepis nana is a segmented tapeworm, not a non-segmented leaf-like parasite.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the most common and smallest tapeworm in humans. Majority of infections are asymptomatic. The drug of choice is praziquantel.

 

Parasites with aquatic plants as the source of infection:

 

  • Fasciola hepatica
  • Fasciolopsis buski
  • Watsonius watsoni
  • Gastrodiscoides hominis

choices.text: They are made up of bacteria and virus
They can be cultured in cell-free media

questions.text: Which of the following statements about prions is true? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. They are infectious proteins

 

Explanation:


Prions are infectious proteins without any nucleic acid. These proteinaceous infectious particles are responsible for transmissible spongiform encephalopathies. Unlike conventional pathogens, prions consist solely of abnormally folded proteins that can induce normal proteins to also misfold, creating a self-propagating infectious agent without genetic material.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. They are made up of bacteria and virus - This is incorrect. Prions are not composed of bacteria or viruses. They are misfolded proteins with no cellular or viral components. Bacteria are complete prokaryotic cells with cell walls and genetic material, while viruses contain nucleic acid (DNA or RNA) surrounded by a protein coat. Prions lack both cellular structures and nucleic acids.

 

Option C. They have rich nuclear material - This is incorrect. Prions completely lack nucleic acids (DNA or RNA), which distinguishes them from all other infectious agents. They are purely protein in nature with no genetic material whatsoever.

 

Option D. They can be cultured in cell-free media - This is incorrect. Prions cannot be cultivated on cell-free media because they lack the metabolic machinery for self-replication. Unlike bacteria which can grow on nutrient media, prions require host cellular machinery to propagate. They replicate by converting normal proteins to the pathogenic form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prions represent a unique class of infectious agents consisting solely of misfolded proteins without nucleic acids, challenging the central dogma that transmission of biological information requires DNA or RNA.

questions.text: All of the following species of Borrelia are associated with tick-borne relapsing fever, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Borrelia recurrentis

 

Explanation:

 

Borrelia recurrentis is associated with louse-borne relapsing fever (epidemic relapsing fever), not tick-borne relapsing fever. This organism is transmitted by the human body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis) and causes epidemic relapsing fever. The disease manifests as recurring episodes of fever separated by periods of apparent recovery, hence the name "relapsing fever." B. recurrentis is the only species in this group that uses lice as its vector rather than ticks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Borrelia hermsii - This species causes endemic (tick-borne) relapsing fever. It is transmitted by soft ticks and is one of the common causes of tick-borne relapsing fever in North America.

 

Option C. Borrelia turicatae - This species causes tick-borne relapsing fever and is transmitted by soft ticks of the genus Ornithodoros. It is endemic in certain regions and belongs to the tick-borne group of relapsing fever Borrelia.

 

Option D. Borrelia duttonii - This species causes tick-borne relapsing fever in Africa. It is transmitted by the soft tick Ornithodoros moubata and causes endemic relapsing fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Borrelia recurrentis is the only species among those listed that causes louse-borne epidemic relapsing fever, while the other species (B. hermsii, B. turicatae, and B. duttonii) cause tick-borne endemic relapsing fever.

questions.text: BCYE medium is used to culture? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Legionella

 

BCYE medium (buffered charcoal yeast extract agar) is used to culture Legionella pneumophila. Legionella pneumophila has fastidious growth requirements and grows on complex media such as BCYE medium with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements (e.g, polymyxin B, cefazolin, vancomycin). The charcoal acts as a detoxifying agent. It grows slowly, and the colonies may take 3-6 days to appear.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Leptospira is cultured on EMJH (Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson and Harris) medium

 

Option B: Bacillus cereus is cultured on PEMBA (Polymyxin pyruvate egg-yolk mannitol-bromothymol blue) agar, which includes Polymyxin, pyruvate, egg yolk, mannitol, and bromothymol blue to differentiate it from other organisms.

 

Option C: Campylobacter is cultured on selective media such as Skirrow's, Campy BAP or Butzler's agar.

 

Educational Objective

 

BCYE medium is essential for the successful isolation and culture of Legionella species, particularly Legionella pneumophila, from environmental and clinical specimens. This medium meets the specific nutritional requirements and provides a protective environment for the growth of this pathogen.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain since 4 days with a history of remitting fever and bradycardia after having meals outside frequently. Which test can be done in the patient to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood culture

 

The patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, remitting fever, bradycardia, and a history of eating meals outside suggest a diagnosis of typhoidal salmonella. In the early phase of this infection, particularly within the first week, the most appropriate diagnostic test is a blood culture. Blood cultures are most effective in detecting Salmonella bacteria during the initial week of illness, which aligns with the patient's 4-day history of symptoms. Early detection through blood culture is crucial for initiating appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Widal test: This test is typically performed in the second week of illness when antibodies against Salmonella begin to rise. Since the patient is only 4 days into the illness, the Widal test is not the most reliable at this stage.

 

Option C. Urine culture: Urine cultures may become positive later in the course of typhoid fever, typically in the third or fourth week. It is not useful in the early stages of the disease.

 

Option D. Stool culture: Stool cultures are generally useful in the later stages of typhoid fever, around the third week. They are not as effective for early detection within the first week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected cases of typhoidal salmonella presenting within the first week of symptoms, a blood culture is the most appropriate diagnostic test.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary identification made by a CBNAAT or GeneXpert? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTB + Rifampicin resistance

 

Explanation:

 

The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT), also known as GeneXpert, is a molecular diagnostic test used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin.

 

The key points are:

 

  1. CBNAAT or GeneXpert is a molecular method based on real-time PCR that can detect the presence of MTB. (Detection  limit  à about 131 bacilli/mL of specimen)
  2. In addition to detecting MTB, it can also detect resistance to the drug rifampicin by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance
  3. CBNAAT/GeneXpert primarily identifies the presence of MTB and rifampicin resistance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: While CBNAAT can detect the presence of MTB, it also provides information on rifampicin resistance, making this option incomplete.

 

Option C. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Isoniazid resistance: CBNAAT does not directly detect resistance to isoniazid, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.

 

Option D. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Ethambutol resistance: CBNAAT does not detect resistance to ethambutol, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT or GeneXpert) is a molecular diagnostic tool that primarily identifies the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin by detecting mutations in the rpoB gene.

 

Additional Information –

 

Laboratory Diagnosis

 

  1. Direct microscopy by acid-fast staining
  2. Kinyoun’s Cold acid-fast Staining
  3. Fluorescence Staining
  4. Culture Methods
    1. Conventional Media
    2. Automated Liquid Culture  à BACTEC MGIT
  5. Molecular Methods

  6. Polymerase Chain reaction (PCR)

  7. Automated real Time PCR  à  CBNAAT, TrueNat

 

RNTCP diagnostic algorithm -

questions.text: A stool sample is collected. The specimen is processed for examination and is labeled at different levels as A, B, C, and D. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

The above image shows formal ether sedimentation technique.

 

Sedimentation techniques use solutions of lower specific gravity than the parasitic organisms, thus concentrating the latter in the sediment. It takes advantage of the high specific gravity of protozoan cysts and helminth eggs compared to water. Their natural tendency to settle out in aqueous solutions can be accelerated by light centrifugation.

 

Formalin fixes the eggs, larvae, oocysts, and spores, so that they are no longer infectious, as well as preserves their morphology. Fecal debris is extracted into the ethyl acetate phase of the solution. Parasitic elements are sedimented at the bottom.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. A: This level contains ether, which is used to extract fecal debris and is found at the top of the tube after centrifugation.

 

Option B. B: This level contains the plug of debris, which is a layer of waste material that is separated from the parasitic elements and sits below the ether layer.

 

Option C. C: This level contains formalin, which fixes and preserves the morphology of the parasitic elements. The formalin layer sits above the sediment but below the plug of debris.

 

Educational Objective

 

In the formal ether sedimentation technique, parasitic ova, cysts, and larvae will be concentrated in the sediment at the bottom of the tube, labeled as level D. This sediment is where parasitic elements are found and examined under a microscope.

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulins shows highest concentration in the serum? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ig-G

 

IgG is the most abundant immunoglobulin in the serum. It plays a crucial role in the body's immune response by neutralizing pathogens, opsonizing for phagocytosis, and activating the complement system. IgG is also the only immunoglobulin that can cross the placenta, providing passive immunity to the fetus.

 

Immunoglobulins concentration in the serum are as follow -

 

Ig-G > Ig-A > Ig-M > Ig-D > Ig-E

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ig-M: Incorrect. While IgM is the first antibody to respond to an infection, it is not the most abundant in the serum.

 

Option B. Ig-A: Incorrect. IgA is present in mucosal areas and secretions, but not in the highest concentration in the serum.

 

Option C. Ig-E: Incorrect. IgE is the least abundant in the serum and is primarily involved in allergic responses.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is not classified as a dimorphic fungus? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryptococcus neoformans

 

Dimorphic fungi are organisms that exist in two different morphological forms depending on temperature - as yeasts at body temperature (37°C) and as molds at environmental temperature (25°C). 

 

Mnemonic: "Para, Penny Can Have Both Shapes" - the dimorphic fungi:

 

  • Paracoccidioides
  • Penicillium marneffei (now called Talaromyces marneffei)
  • Coccidioides 
  • Histoplasma 
  • Blastomyces 
  • Sporothrix

 

These fungi exhibit thermal dimorphism as an adaptation mechanism. 

 

Cryptococcus neoformans, however, is a true yeast that exists only in the yeast form regardless of temperature. It produces encapsulated budding yeast cells with a polysaccharide capsule made of glucuronoxylomannan, which is an important virulence factor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histoplasma capsulatum: This is a classic dimorphic fungus that causes histoplasmosis. At 37°C, it exists as small oval yeast cells (2-4 μm) with narrow-based budding found within macrophages. At 25°C, it forms mycelial phase with tuberculate macroconidia and microconidia.

 

Option B. Coccidioides: This dimorphic fungus causes coccidioidomycosis (Valley fever). It forms spherules containing endospores at 37°C in tissue, while at 25°C it produces arthroconidia in its mycelial form.

 

Option D. Talaromyces marneffei: Formerly known as Penicillium marneffei, this is a dimorphic fungus endemic to Southeast Asia. It shows yeast form at 37°C and mold form with characteristic red pigment production at 25°C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans is a true yeast (not dimorphic) that exists only in yeast form with an encapsulated structure, while dimorphic fungi (Histoplasma, Coccidioides, Blastomyces, Paracoccidioides, Sporothrix, and Talaromyces) can switch between yeast and mold forms based on temperature.

questions.text: A five-year-old child presents with pustular lesions on the lower legs. The culture from the lesions shows hemolytic gram-positive cocci. Which test would best aid in the provisional diagnosis of Group A streptococcal pyoderma? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Bacitracin sensitivity

 

Explanation:

 

Bacitracin sensitivity is the most appropriate test for identifying Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) from the pustular lesions. Group A streptococci are characteristically sensitive to bacitracin, which serves as a key identifying feature in the laboratory. This susceptibility pattern helps differentiate S. pyogenes from other beta-hemolytic streptococci, particularly Group B streptococci which are typically resistant to bacitracin. In the clinical context of a child with pustular skin lesions and isolation of beta-hemolytic gram-positive cocci, the bacitracin sensitivity test is an essential diagnostic tool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase positive test - This is incorrect because streptococci, including Group A Streptococcus, are catalase negative. The catalase test is primarily used to differentiate staphylococci (catalase positive) from streptococci (catalase negative). While Staphylococcus species can cause pustular skin lesions, the question specifically asks about diagnosing Group A streptococcal pyoderma.

 

Option B. Optochin sensitivity - This is incorrect because optochin sensitivity is used specifically for identifying Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococci). Group A streptococci are not characteristically sensitive to optochin. This test helps differentiate pneumococci from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci but is not useful for identifying beta-hemolytic Group A streptococci.

 

Option C. Bile solubility - This is incorrect because the bile solubility test is specific for Streptococcus pneumoniae. Pneumococci are soluble in bile while other streptococci, including Group A Streptococcus, are not. This test is not used in the identification of beta-hemolytic streptococci causing skin infections.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bacitracin sensitivity testing is a critical diagnostic tool for the presumptive identification of Group A Streptococcus (S. pyogenes) in clinical specimens, with sensitivity to bacitracin differentiating it from other beta-hemolytic streptococci, particularly Group B streptococci which are typically resistant.

questions.text: A patient who was on steroids for the treatment of chronic urticaria presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of respiratory symptoms. He says that he has been having nocturnal cough for last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen following bronchoscopy showed the presence of certain larvae as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The presence of eosinophilia in an immunosuppressed patient with respiratory symptoms and BAL revealing rhabditiform larvae is suggestive of disseminated strongyloidiasis caused by Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Strongyloidiasis:

 

Strongyloides are ovoviviparous. The transmission of infection occurs through penetration of the skin by filariform larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine. The larvae moult twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

 

The life cycle of strongyloides is shown below.

 

 

It is generally a benign and asymptomatic condition. In some cases, there may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations. Pulmonary manifestations occur when the larva escapes from the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli leading to bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthmatic symptoms.

 

The term larva currens (meaning 'racing larvae') has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis. These often follow autoinfection and start perianally. Disseminated Strongyloidiasis is seen in immunodeficient individuals.

 

Larva currens is shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of larvae of nonhuman species of nematodes that infect via the oral route.

 

Etiological agents causing visceral larva migrans:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Human nematode: Ascaris lumbricoides, Strongyloides stercoralis.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Zoophilic nematode: Toxocara canis, toxocara cati, Angiostrongylus cantoniensis, Angiostrongylus costaricensis, Anisakis.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Non human nematode: Filarial species, Brugia pahangi, Brugia pate

 

Laboratory diagnosis of strongyloidiasis:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eosinophilia and raised IgE levels.
  • ﻿﻿Microscopic examination of the direct wet mount of the stool demonstrating rhabditiform larvae forms the definitive diagnosis
  • ﻿﻿Stool culture and serological tests are also done

 

Treatment: Ivermectin is the preferred agent in the management of strongyloidiasis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma canium presents with creeping eruption. Cutaneous larva migrans or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

Option B. Capillaria phillipinesis can also cause auto-infection. It commonly presents with severe diarrhea.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection presents as itching (pruritus) and restless sleep (due to nocturnal perianal or perineal pruritus)

 

Educational Objective

 

In patients presenting with respiratory symptoms and eosinophilia, especially those who are immunocompromised, strongyloidiasis should be considered. Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent the severe outcomes associated with hyperinfection. Treatment typically involves antiparasitic medications such as ivermectin.

 

Autoinfection: - CHEST (Mnemonic)

 

  1. Cryptosporidium parvum
  2. H. nana larva
  3. Enterobius vermicularis
  4. Strongyloides
  5. Taenia solium

questions.text: All of the following methods of cold sterilization except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Autoclave

 

Cold sterilization refers to sterilization methods that do not involve heat application. Autoclave operates at 121°C for 15 minutes at 15 PSI pressure, making it a hot sterilization method rather than a cold sterilization technique.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Plasma sterilization: 

 

  • This is a valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses gases in plasma state without temperature increase
  • Effective for heat-sensitive materials

 

Option B. Gamma rays: 

 

  • Valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses ionizing radiation
  • Does not increase temperature
  • Commonly used for medical devices and supplies

 

Option C. UV rays: 

 

  • Valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses non-ionizing radiation
  • Does not generate heat
  • Effective for surface sterilization

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Autoclave is a hot sterilization method operating at 121°C for 15 minutes at 15 PSI pressure, while plasma sterilization, gamma rays, and UV rays are cold sterilization methods that do not involve heat application.

questions.text: Identify the component responsible for endotoxic shock in gram-negative bacteria? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

1 represents the lipopolysaccharide component which is responsible for endotoxic shock in a gram-negative cell wall.

 

 

Conventional gram-negative (LPS-diderm) bacteria display these characteristics:

 

  • An inner cell membrane is present (cytoplasmic)
  • A thin peptidoglycan layer is present (this is much thicker in gram-positive bacteria)
  • Has outer membrane containing lipopolysaccharides (LPS, which consists of lipid A, core polysaccharide, and O antigen) in its outer leaflet and phospholipids in the inner leaflet
  • Porins exist in the outer membrane, which act like pores for particular molecules
  • Between the outer membrane and the cytoplasmic membrane there is a space filled with a concentrated gel-like substance called periplasm
  • The S-layer is directly attached to the outer membrane rather than to the peptidoglycan
  • If present, flagella have four supporting rings instead of two
  • Teichoic acids or lipoteichoic acids are absent
  • Lipoproteins are attached to the polysaccharide backbone
  • Some contain Braun's lipoprotein, which serves as a link between the outer membrane and the peptidoglycan chain by a covalent bond

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2: Incorrect: Number 2 represents the flagella, which are responsible for bacterial motility, not endotoxic shock.

 

Option B. 4: Incorrect: Number 4 represents the cytoplasmic membrane, which is not involved in causing endotoxic shock.

 

Option D. 3: Incorrect: Number 3 represents the peptidoglycan layer, which provides structural support to the bacterial cell wall but does not contribute to endotoxic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between exotoxins and endotoxins

questions.text: Which protein is present in the HPV vaccine? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1

 

9-valent HPV vaccine (Gardasil-9) is a non-infectious recombinant vaccine prepared from the purified virus-like particles (VLPs) of the major capsid (L1) protein of HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

 

Available HPV vaccines protect against either two, four, or nine types of HPV. All HPV vaccines protect against at least HPV types 16 and 18, which cause the greatest risk of cervical cancer. It is estimated that HPV vaccines may prevent 70% of cervical cancer, 80% of anal cancer, 60% of vaginal cancer, 40% of vulvar cancer, and show more than 90% efficacy in preventing HPV-positive oropharyngeal cancers. They additionally prevent some genital warts, with the quadrivalent and nonavalent vaccines that protect against HPV types HPV-6 and HPV-11 providing greater protection.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. E6, E7: These proteins are oncogenes that contribute to the development of cancer by interfering with tumor suppressor proteins such as p53 and Rb but are not components of the vaccine.

 

Option C. E1, E2: These are early proteins involved in the replication and regulation of HPV DNA but are not used in the vaccine formulation.

 

Option D. L2: This is a minor capsid protein of HPV, but the vaccine primarily uses the major capsid protein L1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HPV vaccine contains the L1 protein, which forms virus-like particles that induce an immune response to prevent infection by various HPV types, significantly reducing the risk of HPV-associated cancers and genital warts.

questions.text: A person arrived with a lesion on their left buttock. This individual has a past medical record of undergoing a heart transplant 15 years ago. Analysis of the fluid extracted from the lesion reveals the presence of gram-positive filamentous bacteria. What is the probable microbial agent responsible for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia

 

The provided clinical situation involving a localized abscess and an aspirate displaying filamentous gram-positive bacteria indicates a likelihood of Nocardia infection.

 

  • Nocardia is a gram-positive branching filamentous bacilli.

 

 

  • Modified acid-fast staining: using 1% sulfuric acid as decolorizer (Kinyoun method): Nocardiae are partially acid-fast and appear as branching and filamentous red colored acid-fast bacilli.

 

 

  • Histopathology (H and E stain) of the granules: Shows multilobulated with sun-ray appearance.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Bacillus anthracis, on culture, are arranged end-to-end in long chains → Bamboo-stick appearance.

 

 

Option C. Mycobacterium leprae is an acid-fast, Gram-positive, rod shaped bacterium and an obligate intracellular parasite.

 

 

Option D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis appear weakly Gram-positive. Acid fast stain is used to identify it.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Nocardia is a gram-positive, branching filamentous bacillus, particularly seen in immunocompromised patients, and can be identified using modified acid-fast staining.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ig A

 

The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

 

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

 

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

 

  • ﻿﻿J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
  • ﻿﻿Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ig G: Typically exists as a monomer and is the most abundant immunoglobulin in the blood and extracellular fluid.

 

Option C. Ig M: The largest antibody, mainly in pentameric form, being the first antibody to be produced in response to an infection.

 

Option D. Ig E: Involved in allergic reactions and parasitic infections, known for its role in the immune response to allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory IgA is critical for mucosal immunity due to its unique structure and location. It acts as the first line of defence by preventing pathogens from adhering to and penetrating mucosal surfaces, thus playing a vital role in protecting the body from infections, especially at the mucosal barriers.

questions.text: Which extracellular cell adhesion is disrupted by Vibrio cholerae? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occludens

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae disrupts occludens, specifically targeting tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, which impairs their barrier function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Integrin: Primarily involved in cell-extracellular matrix adhesion, not typically disrupted by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option B. Cadherin: Important for cell-cell adhesion in adherens junctions, not the main target of Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect, as occludens are indeed affected by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio cholerae specifically targets occludens, which are crucial components of tight junctions, thereby compromising intestinal epithelial barrier functions.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presented with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, night fever and chills, calf tenderness, cervical lymphadenopathy, hypokalemia, and joint pain. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

Leptospirosis is the Ans.  because the patient's presentation of symptoms, particularly conjunctival suffusion (redness of the conjunctiva), is more characteristic of Leptospirosis than the other conditions listed. This condition is caused by the Leptospira bacteria, which can lead to symptoms like retro-orbital pain, night fevers, chills, calf tenderness, and hypokalemia, all seen in this patient.

 

The key differentiator in this case is conjunctival suffusion, which is commonly observed in Leptospirosis and is not a typical feature of Dengue or other listed conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria: Malaria usually presents with high fevers, chills, sweats, and headache but does not typically cause conjunctival suffusion or calf tenderness. Additionally, hypokalemia is not a common feature of Malaria.

 

Option C. Filariasis: Filariasis is characterized by lymphatic dysfunction and can cause lymphedema or elephantiasis, but it does not present with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, or the other acute symptoms described in the patient.

 

Option D. Dengue: Dengue can present with similar symptoms such as retro-orbital pain, fever, and joint pain, making it a close differential. However, conjunctival suffusion is not a characteristic feature of Dengue, which helps to distinguish it from Leptospirosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conjunctival suffusion is a distinguishing symptom of Leptospirosis and is not commonly seen in Dengue or other similar infectious conditions.

questions.text: A patient from Uttar Pradesh presented with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear examination showed pancytopenia. Buffy coat examination showed macrophages laden with organisms with a kinetoplast. What is the vector for the likely disease? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sandfly

 

From the given clinical features, the most likely disease is visceral leishmaniasis or Kala azar caused by Leishmania donovani, and the vector is sandfly. A patient from Uttar Pradesh presenting with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly with a smear examination showing pancytopenia and macrophages containing organisms with kinetoplasts point towards the diagnosis.

 

 

Leishmaniasis is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. Patients present with high fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and emaciation. The skin becomes dry, rough, and darkly pigmented. There is anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

 

The parasite exists in 2 forms:

 

  • Amastigote form (also called LD bodies)- It is seen within macrophages and contains a kinetoplast.
  • Promastigote form- It is the infective form in the sandfly. The kinetoplast is seen at the anterior end.

 

Kinetoplast are non-nuclear DNA present in addition to nucleus. They consist of blepharoplast and parabasal body. Flagellum originates near the kinetoplast.

 

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tse-Tse fly: Transmits trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Triatomine bug: Known for spreading Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis).

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito: Vector for malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visceral leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania donovani and transmitted by sandflies, is a severe systemic disease. Recognizing its epidemiology, clinical presentation, and diagnostic features is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment. Awareness and control of the vector, along with appropriate medical intervention, are essential in areas endemic for this disease.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is the most resistant to antiseptics? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Prions

 

Explanation:

 

Prions are the most resistant structures to antiseptics and disinfectants. Prions require specific and extreme sterilization methods compared to other microorganisms. The recommended methods for prion sterilization are particularly aggressive: autoclaving at 134°C for 1 to 1.5 hours, treatment with 1 N NaOH for 1 hour, or using 0.5% sodium hypochlorite for 2 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spores - While bacterial spores are highly resistant to many antiseptics, they are less resistant than prions. Spores can be killed by proper autoclaving (121°C for 15 minutes) or using strong disinfectants like glutaraldehyde (2% for 10-14 hours).

 

Option C. Cysts - Cysts of protozoa are moderately resistant to antiseptics but less resistant than both spores and prions. They don't require the extreme conditions needed for prion inactivation.

 

Option D. Fungi - Fungi are generally susceptible to intermediate-level disinfectants. Intermediate-level disinfectants including alcohols, phenolics, and halogens are effective against fungi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prions require the most extreme sterilization conditions of all infectious agents, including extended high-temperature autoclaving (134°C for 1-1.5 hours) or strong chemical treatment (1N NaOH or concentrated hypochlorite), making them the most resistant structures to antiseptics and disinfection methods.

choices.text: Exanthem subitum
Erythema infectiosum
Hand foot mouth disease

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is characterized by a lacy or reticular rash on the extremities and "slapped cheek" appearance as shown in the image? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythema infectiosum

 

  • ﻿﻿Caused by parvo B19
  • ﻿﻿SSDNA virus
  • ﻿﻿Non enveloped
  • ﻿﻿Non enveloped DNA virus

 

The initial symptoms of erythema infectiosum include a low-grade fever, headache, and a runny nose. After a few days, a characteristic rash appears on the face, which gives the appearance of "slapped cheeks". The rash then spreads to the trunk, arms, and legs, and can be itchy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exanthem subitum (Roseola infantum): Roseola is caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) and sometimes HHV-7. It typically presents with a sudden high fever that lasts for a few days, followed by a rash that appears as the fever subsides. The rash usually starts on the trunk and spreads to the extremities but does not have the characteristic "slapped cheek" appearance.

 

Option C. Hand, foot, and mouth disease: This disease is caused by enteroviruses, commonly coxsackievirus. It presents with fever, sores in the mouth, and a rash on the hands, feet, and sometimes buttocks. The rash is usually vesicular rather than lacy or reticular.

 

Option D. Mumps: Mumps is caused by the mumps virus, a paramyxovirus. It typically presents with swelling of the parotid glands, fever, and muscle aches, but it does not cause a lacy or reticular rash or the "slapped cheek" appearance.

 

Educational objective:

 

Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) is characterized by a "slapped cheek" rash on the face, followed by a lacy or reticular rash on the extremities. It is caused by parvovirus B19, a non-enveloped, single-stranded DNA virus.

choices.text: Measles virus
Polio virus
Mumps virus

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is presented with swelling on face and scrotum. Which of the following is causative agent? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mumps virus

 

In addition to salivary gland swelling, mumps can cause complications in some cases, particularly in adults. Complications of mumps can include meningitis, encephalitis, inflammation of the testicles or ovaries, and hearing loss.

 

  • ﻿﻿M/c presentation: B/I parotitis
  • ﻿﻿Sometimes parotitis preceded by meningoencephalitis
  • ﻿﻿After 1 or 2 weeks orchitis
  • ﻿﻿Vaccine strain; Jeryl lynn
  • ﻿﻿Negative sense Single stranded RNA virus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measles virus: a member of the Paramyxoviridae family. Disease typically presents with a high fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a characteristic maculopapular rash, but it does not cause facial or scrotal swelling.

 

Option B. Polio virus: An enterovirus, primarily affects the nervous system, leading to paralysis. It does not cause swelling of the face or scrotum.

 

Option D. Cox virus (Coxsackievirus): Coxsackieviruses, members of the Picornaviridae family, can cause a variety of illnesses including hand, foot, and mouth disease, herpangina, and myocarditis. They do not typically cause the combination of facial and scrotal swelling seen in mumps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mumps virus is the causative agent of mumps, which presents with bilateral parotitis (swelling of the parotid glands), and can also cause orchitis (swelling of the testicles) in males. This combination of symptoms—facial swelling and scrotal swelling—is characteristic of mumps infection.

questions.text: Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to the absence of? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T cell

 

Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to absence of T cell.

 

A xenograft is a tissue graft or organ transplant from a donor of a different species.

 

Nude mice lack body hair, hence the name. They lack a thymus and thus cannot generate mature T lymphocytes. The absence of T-lymphocytes makes them unable to mount adaptive immune responses requiring helper T cells and cytotoxic T cells. The absence of functioning T cells also prevents the rejection of allografts & xenografts.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. B cell: Incorrect because the primary immunodeficiency in nude mice relates to T cells, not B cells. While B cells are essential for antibody production, their presence does not compensate for the lack of T cell-mediated immunity necessary for xenograft rejection.

 

Option C. Both B and T cell: Incorrect as nude mice specifically lack T cells due to the absence of a thymus, while B cell function remains intact.

 

Option D. INK cell: Incorrect because the term should likely refer to "NK cells" (natural killer cells), which are not the primary reason for the lack of xenograft rejection in nude mice. NK cells can participate in innate immune responses but do not compensate for the lack of adaptive immune responses mediated by T cells in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


Nude mice lack a thymus, resulting in a deficiency of mature T cells, which are essential for rejecting xenografts. This highlights the crucial role of T cells in adaptive immune responses and graft rejection.

questions.text: The causative agent for St. Anthony's Fire is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Streptococcus

 

Explanation:

 

St. Anthony's Fire is a historical term that refers to erysipelas, an acute infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics. This condition is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), which is characterized by a bright red, swollen, and indurated skin lesion with a distinct raised border. The condition was named "St. Anthony's Fire" due to the intense burning sensation patients experience and the fiery red appearance of the affected skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Staphylococcus Staphylococcus species, particularly S. aureus, typically cause skin infections such as furuncles, carbuncles, impetigo and wound infections. While they can cause cellulitis, they do not cause the classical erysipelas (St. Anthony's Fire) with its characteristic raised borders and bright red appearance.

 

Option C: Klebsiella Klebsiella is a Gram-negative bacillus of the Enterobacteriaceae family. It is primarily associated with pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and septicemia, particularly in hospitalized patients. It is not associated with erysipelas or St. Anthony's Fire.

 

Option D: Nocardia Nocardia is an aerobic Gram-positive bacterium that causes nocardiosis, which typically presents as a pulmonary infection with possible dissemination to other organs, particularly the brain. It also can cause cutaneous infections, but these typically present as abscesses or mycetomas, not as erysipelas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

St. Anthony's Fire (erysipelas) is a distinctive streptococcal skin infection characterized by sharply demarcated, bright red, indurated lesions with raised borders, caused specifically by Streptococcus pyogenes.

questions.text: A South Asian fruit farmer presented with fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nipah virus

 

The Nipah virus is known to be transmitted by fruit bats, specifically the Pteropus species, which are commonly found in South Asia. The virus can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis in humans, symptoms that match the presentation in this case (fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis). The close association between fruit farming and fruit bats increases the risk of transmission, especially in South Asia where the Nipah virus is more prevalent.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zika virus: Zika virus is primarily transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and is known for causing fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. It does not cause severe respiratory symptoms or encephalitis as described in this case.

 

Option C. Malaria: Malaria is caused by Plasmodium species and transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes. It presents with fever, chills, and other systemic symptoms, but it does not typically cause breathlessness or encephalitis.

 

Option D. Ebola virus: Although Ebola can be associated with bats, it primarily causes hemorrhagic fever and is less associated with respiratory symptoms or encephalitis compared to Nipah virus. Also, Ebola is more commonly linked with direct human-to-human transmission or through contact with infected animals' bodily fluids.
